body:
At the surface, both are social platforms centered around topics. We've seen Reddit recently introduce similar features such as avatars visible in the comments and live chat.

It seems that every subreddit has its own Discord server as well.

What are your thoughts?
body_html:
At the surface, both are social platforms centered around topics. We've seen Reddit recently introduce similar features such as avatars visible in the comments and live chat.

It seems that every subreddit has its own Discord server as well.

What are your thoughts?
title: Do you think Reddit feels threatened by Discord?

body: Discord has half of the cancer problem that Reddit does. While supermods aren't really a thing on Discord their admins are total cancer. Banning people literally for no reason, allowing child porn, etc etc. Honestly I don't see Discord lasting more than 2-3 years before its replaced.
body_html: Discord has half of the cancer problem that Reddit does. While supermods aren't really a thing on Discord their admins are total cancer. Banning people literally for no reason, allowing child porn, etc etc. Honestly I don't see Discord lasting more than 2-3 years before its replaced.

body:
I dunno, I like the idea of a super focused community that discord provides, but in practice its kind of a mess.

I prefer the reddit/ruqqy style myself.

Most of my discords I stay silent, its just a free for all clusterfuck.

Maybe my channels just suck, I dunno

post.title: Do you think Reddit feels threatened by Discord?

body: So was Reddit for the longest time, but then cracks started showing. Discord, for example, still to this day does not support spellcheck on Linux when the Electron framework they use supports it, plus they have supposedly not figured out desktop streaming from Linux yet. Not only that but they just got hit with the second [plugin-based malware](https://www.pocket-lint.com/apps/news/152340-discord-malware-is-stealing-users-passwords) which wouldn't be an issue if they just officially supported 3rd party plugins.
body_html: So was Reddit for the longest time, but then cracks started showing. Discord, for example, still to this day does not support spellcheck on Linux when the Electron framework they use supports it, plus they have supposedly not figured out desktop streaming from Linux yet. Not only that but they just got hit with the second plugin-based malware which wouldn't be an issue if they just officially supported 3rd party plugins.

body: I think reddit's trying to adapt the Facebook/Twitter model more than anything right now. They've never been a live chat room, although they did introduce the chat feature it's never been a big focus for them. The biggest evidence of this is how reddit admins and their friends, the DefaultMods power users, seem intent on attaching users to their real life identity and gaining personal information, when before you were supposed to be anonymous.
body_html: I think reddit's trying to adapt the Facebook/Twitter model more than anything right now. They've never been a live chat room, although they did introduce the chat feature it's never been a big focus for them. The biggest evidence of this is how reddit admins and their friends, the DefaultMods power users, seem intent on attaching users to their real life identity and gaining personal information, when before you were supposed to be anonymous.

body: I feel like people like discord more in general, I don't believe Reddit is intimidated by discord though because of how actually different they are. Like what do most people use Reddit for mostly? Probably memes and news. But what do most people use discord for? Talking to people
